Data : Writer received a call at approximately 1700 from son Peter. Son mentioned that resident had called him and informed him that she had no tenant briefs in her room and that staff could not toilet her because of lack of products. Action : Writer spoke with PSW staff and was informed resident had 8 tena "back up briefs" in her bathroom cabinet but was refusing to let staff utilize a brief stating they were for emergencies. PSW staff told resident that once dinner service was completed writer or RCM would go down to get more tena, however they would have to use the brief in her room for now. Resident refused to be toileted and refused to come for dinner. Resident also contacted her son. Writer informed son that resident did have extra briefs but refused to utilize them until writer had an opportunity to go and get her more. Son understood and asked that going forward maybe have PSW more aware if resident was running low of her "non emergency stock". Response : Residents dinner was saved and resident called PSW staff at 1730 and agreed to use 1 out of the 8 briefs she had in her room and asked to be toileted, which PSW staff did immediately. Resident came down to the dining room after being toileted for dinner. SIGNED]

Data : The Writer was approached by the resident just prior to lunch asking if the Writer has spoken to her son. The Writer asked why, to which she responded 'about our situation'. The Writer asked about which situation she was referring to, she replied 'about the room change'. The Writer reiterated the conversation had yesterday with the resident, to which the resident responded 'I'd call Peter if I were you', smirked at Writer and then turned away. Action : The Writer and co-nurse (T.S) attempted to call Peter (son) twice with no response. The Writer did leave a voicemail stating it was not an urgent phone call but that Writer would like to connect today before 4pm. The Writer did also leave a call back extension for him to call. Response : Pending response at this time. SIGNED]

Data : The resident approached the Writer just prior to lunch, stating she was speaking with the co-resident (M.A)'s husband. The resident began to relay information shared by the co-resident's husband regarding interventions implemented by the home that are notrelevant to the resident and her care. The Writer stopped the topic immediately, expressed that the Writer would not continue with the conversation relating to a co-resident's personal information/care. The Writer validated the resident's concern and explained the importance of confidentiality within the home and dignity of others; the resident then replied 'well that's just ignorant'. The Writer apologized that the resident felt frustrated with the response but that no details of other residents can be discussed with her. The resident then asked about a room change due to not liking her roommate; The Writer explained that at this time we do not have any open rooms for her to move to, however, the admissions coordinator and social service coordinator areaware of this request and will make the accommodation as soon as they have availability. The Writer also explained that there is no guarantee on who the new roommate would be which could furthermore land the resident in the same position as she's currently in, but that we'd try our best to accommodate and arrange for a roommate who would be a good fit; resident ok with this. LATE ENTRY Note Text : Assessed on medical rounds. Recently, resident noted to have some blood per rectum. Initially blood was noted with a bowel movement and subsequently blood had been noticed on her incontinence product. She does not have a history of lower GI diagnoses or GI bleed. She is not on a blood thinner. Bowel movements documented as regular, stools usually soft to formed. She had no apparent pain, intakes stable. O/E resident was seen resting quietly in her bed. Eyes open, nystagmus noted, pupils somewhat fixed and dilated. She was not able to answer any questions pertaining to vision, and did not seem to have any response to sudden movements in her near field of vision. Abdomen soft and benign. No visible abnormalities on assessment of anal lesion. Skin intact. No bleeding at this time. Update provided to POA/son by phone. Rectal bleeding quite possibly related to hemorrhoids, but cannot rule out other underlying etiology including more serious diagnosis such as malignancy. Son aware. Given impression of chronic disease, frailty, dementia, etc., POA identified that conservative management in the home with a focus on palliative approach and comfort are the goals for this resident at this time. No aggressive investigations or interventions, and plan for care in the home rather than transfer to hospital should her health condition decline. We also reviewed resident's vision. Sometime ago, there appeared to be ocular erythema but resident was persistent about keeping her eyes close, and further assessment was not possible. POA wished for conservative approach/expectant management. At this time, it appears that resident has had significant vision loss and is likely blind. POA indicates that he does not wish to proceed with further investigations such as via optometry/ophthalmology assessment. Lower GI bleed, likely hemorrhoids. Monitor for any further health concerns. Significant vision loss. Palliative approach. Dictated by Dr. Lee Andersen dictated but not read [e-SIGNED]

LATE ENTRY Note Text : Assessed on medical rounds. Due to concerns regarding left ear discharge/wax. Order was provided to flush left ear for wax removal, following assessment with otoscopy last week. Otoscopy showed tan/brown accumulated matter in external auditory canal appearing consistent with cerumen. Visualization of the TM was limited, but partial view indicated no concerns. Upon flushing ear, nursing staff noted that water did not collect in collecting basin, but instead drain rapidly from resident's nose. Resident did not indicate any pain or significant discomfort. This was reported to the POA, who indicated that resident has not experienced similar in the past. Today resident reports that soft food or fluids some times come out of her nose when she is attempting to eat/drink. POA indicate that she experienced this long standing, and it is not new. Resident today reports some discomfort in her buttock as well as ongoing discomfort in her stomach. Resident was seen alert, seated in chair, appeared calm and comfortable. Otoscopy revealed a small amount of tan/brown material in external auditory canal which again appears consistent with cerumen. Visualization of the TM was slightly limited, with the appearance of some cerumen/debris in front of the TM. No defect was visualized. Mouth and oral pharynx unremarkable. Abdomen benign, some lower abdominal tenderness reported with palpation. Abdominal x-ray showed fecal loading of the large bowel. Urine culture showed no growth. Possible middle/inner ear pathology with communication to nasal pharynx. Resident is generally asymptomatic. Offer referral to ENT, but monitoring/expectant management may be appropriate for this resident. Abdominal pain possibly secondary to constipation. Increase Senokot to two tabs routinely and two tabs prn, plus PEG 3350 17 grams po daily. Follow regarding bowel pattern. Also of note, wheelchair seat cushion has been assessed and inflation adjusted. Monitor regarding buttock pain. Consider adjustment of Butran's if ongoing concerns regarding pain. LATE ENTRY Note Text : Assessed on medical rounds. POA has expressed concern regarding resident reporting discomfort in her buttocks as well as lower abdominal discomfort. Due to previous concerns regarding left hip pain, resident is on Butran's 5 patch as well as Tylenol routinely. She also has Pregabalin and Hydromorph bid prior to cares. Resident reports discomfort in her buttocks primarily when she is seated in her wheelchair. She indicates the discomfort is "all over" her buttocks. It is better when she is resting inbed, she also reports some lower abdominal discomfort and dysuria. Intakes have been stable, no vomiting, no concerns regarding bowel pattern. She has a history of UTI. Due to dark colored discharge from her left ear, Polysporin ear drops were provided by on-call MD. Resident denies any ear pain. O/E resident was alert, in bed, answers questions. Color okay, slightly pale. Mucus membranes moist, resps easy and regular. Abdomen reveal normal bowel sounds, soft, mild tenderness reported with palpation across the lower abdomen, no masses detected and no peritoneal findings. Skin on the buttocks and perianal area intact with no visible abnormalities, no redness or other findings. Otoscopy shows what appears to be accumulated cerumen, dark in color in the auditory canal. Assessment and Plan: Regarding buttock discomfort, I have requested assessment of resident's wheelchair cushion to ensure it is appropriately inflated, and minimize pressure. Regarding lower abdominal discomfort, urine culture has been ordered as well as U/S. Left ear to be flush for wax removal. On follow-up, if concerns regarding pain persists, consideration could be given to increase in Butran's patch. Follow. Dictated by Dr. Lee Andersen dictated but not read [e-SIGNED]

LATE ENTRY Note Text : Case conference held today, including resident's POA, myself and ADOC DP. Reviewed resident's recent health condition, goals of care. In summary, after a fall with minor head injury and laceration, resident was transferred to the Emergency Department. Laceration was closed with staples, but due to confusion/agitation she was admitted to hospital with delirium. Possible pneumonia based on x-ray findings, course of treatment with antibiotics completed. Ongoing delirium, confusion, falls risk, poor oral intakes requiring IV hydration. Health condition stabilized and discharged back to Mill Creek. Since her return, signs of ongoing delirium. No focal symptoms. Decline in function/mobility, decline in cognition. Food intakes often poor, 0 to 25% and fluid intakes variable. For pain management she is receiving prn Hydromorphone 0 to 3 times per day, usually effective. Bloodwork and urine culture have been ordered regarding ongoing delirium. Possible triggers for deli rum discussed, uncertain prognosis and potentially chronic course of delirium discussed. Goals of care discussed. Due to chronic disease, dementia, and recent decline with delirium, family understand that prognosis for recovery is guarded. Wishes are for resident to receive medical management in the home, and should her health condition decline, she will receive treatment and comfort care measures in the home if needed. Goals of care do not include transfer to hospital. Family expressed wishes to ensure that resident is comfortable, painmanaged, and falls risk reduced. They are agreeable to current treatment plan, including pending investigations with blood work and urine culture. RD will be involved regarding nutrition and supplementation, and weights will be followed. VS continueto be monitored as well as pain tracking. DP further addressed concerns regarding falls prevention. Dictated by Dr. Lee Andersen dictated but not read [e-SIGNED]

LATE ENTRY Note Text : Assessed on medical rounds. It is noted that resident had an episode on September 19 described as a "blank stare" for about one minute which occurred after he had been standing and banging his wheelchair. Decreased tone in the limbs was noted, and resident appeared pale at the time. On September 22nd, at approximately 1100 hours resident sustained a fall with no apparent injuries and BP after the incident was noted to be 72/45. He was monitored on head injury routine. Resident does have a known diagnosis of orthostatic hypotension, and receives Midodrine in the morning. Yesterday September 23rd in the evening resident sustained a fall in his room with a scalp laceration. He became agitated when staff attempted to assess VS, and chased staff out of his room, through the corridor and in to the common area. He was not clothed at the time. When given space, resident calmed down and returned to his room. Today, in conversation, resident has a clear memory of these events. He does not remember the circumstances of his fall, but think that he had been sleeping. He describes waking from a deep sleep, finding several Page 1 of 5 Note Effective Date Range: 09/01/2025 to 09/30/2025 Effective Time Range: All Created Date Range: All Created Time Range: All Author: All Department: All Resident Name : HUYER, JACOB (001105) Location : 3 West W319 1 Admission 01/29/2025 Date : (N39.0), Dementia in Parkinson's disease(F02.3), Delirium, unspecified(F05.9), Stroke, not specified as haemorrhage or infarction(I64) people around him and talking. He describes being poorly oriented due to just waking, and states that he became aggravated and chasedthe staff. He reports that they were laughing and screaming, like it was a game, so he continued to chase them and "over did it". He sat down when he became tired. Resident also spoke about his ongoing difficulty dealing with life changes, chronic disease (namely Parkinson's), moving to LTC, not living in the community with is wife, change in the relationship with his wife, frustration regarding lack of sexual activity. He reports that all of these are upsetting for him, and he continues to struggle with his mood. Resident also reports constipation with stools being hard, "like small balls". He denied any new health related concerns or symptoms on screening assessment. VS at the time of the fall last evening were stable. Today resident was seen seated quietly in his room, initially sleeping. After waking, he was lucid and conversational. Color normal, resps easy and regular. No tremor or dystonia noted. Small laceration on the frontal scalp with dry blood. Assessment and Plan: Recurrent falls related to Parkinson's disease and orthostatic hypotension. Episodic behaviour related to Parkinson's dementia, environmental triggers. In discussion with resident he indicated that he would like to trial Sertraline to address mood concerns.Sertraline increased from 75 mg to 100 mg po daily. He continues on Quetiapine. Postural VS have been ordered and will be reassess next week, with reassessment of Midodrine dosing at that time. For bowel irregularity/constipation add Clearlax 17 grams daily, and Senokot two tabs routinely plus two tabs prn for constipation. Dictated by Dr. Lee Andersen, dictated but not read [e-SIGNED]

Type of Behaviour : Physical expressions exhibiting by throwing of items within reach ie. dishes, personal items, shelving unit/dresser etc, and attempts at pushing and/or punching staff. Verbal expressions exhibited by yelling and threatening to injury staff. Antecedent/Triggers : Writer was informed by Jacob he is frustrated with his health decline and loss of full independence. Describe the behaviour : At approx 1700 Writer observed Jacob yelling and throwing items in his room at the walls and door. Jacob was trying to push staff members and threaten to injury them. Jacob proceeded to ambulate throughout the unit without use of walker and placed himselfon the floor. Writer noted Jacob try to enter co-resident room. Disruptiveness (Data)/Consequences to the behaviour : Co-resident access to rooms were unavailable due to hallway doors being closed to ensure resident/staff safety. Interventions (review/update care plan) (Action) : Writer maintained a patient approach allowing Jacob to express what was his trigger. Writer and Nurse Manager (B.A) provided Jacob space by asking staff to keep a distance during his escalated behaviors. Writer offered a drink to which Jacob accepted and ensured he was not in pain or injured himself. Jacob's wife Margaret was called to provide support. Change in medication : What are the risks and causes : Resident at risk for injury/fall due to unsteady gait. Outcome(s)(Result) : Writer and NM stayed with Jacob until he was settled and safe at approx 1800. Writer ensured Jacobs's room was clean and all fall intervention equipment was functioning. Jacob stated he was apologetic of incident and is overall frustrated with the declinein his health. Plan of care ongoing in regards to triggers and interventions. Substitute Decision Maker notified (if not, explain) : POA Margaret was appreciative of phone call and grateful for staff support to ensure Jacob was safe.

LATE ENTRY Note Text : Assessed on medical rounds. Due to previous episode of vaginal bleeding, transvaginal ultrasound to assess endometrium was ordered. Further information gathered today. Resident is entirely unsure of her last normal menstrual period. She reports having very irregular periods for which she started taking continuous OCP, she guesses approximately three years ago but cannot clearly remember. She does not recall pathologic diagnoses, surgeries, or concerns. G2 T1 P0, Alc, Ll. Staff notes skin breakdown on the buttocks/thighs. O/E was tired but able to participate in conversation and answer questions. Color okay, resps easy and regular. O/E of the buttocks reveals patches of erythema with erosion/ulceration bilaterally on posterior thighs near the gluteal creases, and additional areas of erythema with some superficial skin breakdown on the superior/medial buttocks bilaterally closer to the coccyx. Recent U/S showed increase endometrial thickness of 1.1 cm with increased vascularity of cystic spaces concerning for endometrial carcinoma. Assessment and Plan: Perimenopausal/Post-menopausal bleeding. Concerning findings on U/S but uncertain significance as resident's menopausal status is not clear. However, referral will be made to gynecology,which resident is aware and agreeable. For skin breakdown related to MASD and pressure, I recommend use of zinc barrier cream for the MASD on the superior buttocks and cleanse and Optifoam on the bilateral posterior thigh wounds. These will be monitor on wound rounds with dressings checked regularly to ensure that they are intact and clean. I have also requested assessment of her wheelchair, seat cushion, etc. for pressure reduction. Follow. LATE ENTRY Note Text : POA expressed concerns regarding possible hallucinations, after Quetiapine was changed to prn last month. POA explains that she has been on Quetiapine for a couple of years and since change to prn, POA notes that resident has been talking about seeing people in her room, seeing things crawling on her food and insects in her room. POA also finds that she is more agitated/irritable during phone conversations. He believes that the hallucinations are disturbing for her with a negative impact on her quality of life. Risks and side effects associated with atypical antipsychotics were reviewed, including increase in cardiovascular risks (heart attack, stroke, cardiovascular death). POA understands and feels that potential benefit for this resident outweighs the risk. Based on Canadian guidelines, further management of BPSD, trial Risperidone 0.125 mg at hs will be added and prn Quetiapine will be discontinued. Monitor regarding BPSD. Dictated by Dr. Lee Andersen dictated but not read [e-SIGNED]

LATE ENTRY Note Text : Assessed on medical rounds. Resident noted to have an acute change in her health condition, functional status today. Staff noted that she required more assistance ambulating to breakfast, and was hunched over the table while at breakfast which is unusual for her. She demonstrated some other unusual behaviour such as licking her toast, following breakfast. She has been sitting in her chair in her room, angled to the left, leaning forward with her face and hands on the left arm rest of the chair. She denies pain, or other complaints. Further information gathered from her POA/son Brian, indicated that she has had a couple of very similar episodes in the past prior to admission to Mill Creek. On one occasion she was transferred to the hospital, where she was found to be dehydrated and possibly with a mild pneumonia. Quetiapine was recently reduced and changed to prn and she remains on Citalopram 30 mg po daily. Resident's daughter-in-law spoke with her two days ago, stating that she was very pleasant and "chipper" with no concerns regarding her mood, change in cognition or health concerns at that time. Intakes today were good at breakfast. Overall, food intakes have been good recently and fluid intakes have been fairly good. She does not have a noted history of CVA or TIA. She does have noted AFIB and is on aspirin but no DOAC. Afebrile, VS stable. Resident seen seated in chair, in position as described above. LATE ENTRY Note Text : Assessed on medical rounds. 1) With respect to lower leg edema, Lasix recently increased as per cardiology recommendation. She continues to wear tubi grips, and is l.5 liter per day fluid restriction. She is not compliant with elevating her feet. Recent weight show some weight loss, however pitting edema continue in bilateral lower extremities. POA is requesting use of Coban rather than tubi grip. Arterial doppler ultrasound will be ordered with ABI, to rule out significant vascular disease before considering higher compression. In the meantime, continue same and follow. 2) With respect to BPSD, reports from staff and notes indicate that resident is sometimes anxious, fearful of being along in her room. She sometimes spends much of the night in her chair in the nursing area. Today at the time of rounds, she was in the nursing station when she asked to be taken back to her room "before they get me". When asked, she indicated that she is afraid, and specified "the powers that be". Due to apparent anxiety, paranoia, fearfulness, resident may benefit from atypical antipsychotic. Trial low dose Risperdal 0.125 mg po daily at hs. Monitor regarding behaviour and titrate. Both of the above were discussed with POA/Kelly by phone, and she was agreeable to the treatment plans. LATE ENTRY Note Text : Assessed on medical rounds. Resident out to see cardiologist at PACE, Dr. Awan. ECG was completed which showed AFIB (known) with ventricular response rate of 92 beats per minute. Cardiology recommendations were to discontinue Amiodarone and start Bisoprolol 2.5 mg daily, discontinue Ramipril/Hydrochlorothiazide and proceed with Ramipril 10 mg po daily and increase Furosemide to 80 mg po bid. I have note yet received a clinic note, and have requested one. Resident continues to have poor sleep cycle, up at time during the night, sometime preferring to remain in nursing station, reportedly fearful to be in her room alone. She also has refusal of care at times. Recent monthly pain management shows that pain management is effective. Intakes have recently been good. She has reported itchy back recently, requesting assistance scratching her back and some excoriation noted. According to Resource Nurse, POA/daughter reported that resident has bruising on her back related to scratching. Most recent weight 92.1 kg representing some weight loss (likely related to diuresis). VS have been stable. Resident seen seated in her wheelchair, alert, appears comfortable and in no distress. Color okay, resps easy and regular. Ongoing bilateral leg edema, slightly improved. Skin on resident's back intact, no rash or erythema, few old fading bruises. Assessment and Plan: New orders provided with respect to presumed CHF, with cardiology note pending. VS will continue to be monitor. Continue to monitor weights, with respect to fluid retention and diuresis. Regarding itch, order provided for Glaxal with 1% Hydrocortisone and quarter percent menthol to be applied to back bid and bid/prn for itch. With respect to BPSD, anxiety/fearfulness, for sleep, consideration could be given to low dose Risperidone. This will be discussed with POA in coming weeks if concerns persists. LATE ENTRY Note Text : Assessed on medical rounds. Noted to have pain with wound care and repositioning. Over the past several days, resident has developed a significant right sided buttock wound. It initially appeared to be an excoriation with small area of bruising, but has significantly progressed, enlarging in size, with dark discoloration that appeared consistent with pressure injury or hematoma prior to skin breakdown. The area is now open, superficial stage 3, base dark maroon. Mild surrounding erythema, blanchable. Images were reviewed on wound rounds to view progression and also assessed in person. Discussed with skin and wound coordinator. Wound will be cleansed with VASHE, and cover with Optifoam. This will need to be checked frequently depending on location and likely difficulty maintaining intact and clean dressing. Optimize pressure relief. Skin and wound coordinator will be looking in to an air mattress. Pain tracking has been requested, Voltaren added for low back pain and Hydromorphone 0.5 mg po bid prn prior to wound care has also been ordered. Follow. Action : Writer explained that resident should have dressings changed twice daily but up until yesterday, resident refused to have them changed more than once daily, and after showers, did not want his dressings applied until after breakfast for worry that he would miss breakfast. He also refused to have his dressing changed earlier in the AM and refused care and dressing changes from night staff as well, Page 2 of 3 Note Effective Date Range: 09/01/2025 to 09/30/2025 Effective Time Range: All Created Date Range: All Created Time Range: All Author: All Department: All Resident Name : MORIN, YVON JOHN (00722) Location : 2 East E201 2 Admission 04/16/2019 Date : affective disorder, unspecified(F31.9), Arthritis, unspecified, unspecified site(M13.99), Diverticular disease of intestine, part unspecified, without perforation or abscess(K57.9), Peripheral vascular disease, unspecified(I73.9), Acute haematogenous osteomyelitis, unspecified site(M86.09), Obesity, unspecified(E66.9), Localized oedema(R60.0), Other specified abnormal findings of blood chemistry(R79.8), Resistance to methicillin(U82.1), Resistance to other specified extended spectrum betalactam antibiotics(U82.28), Cellulitis of other sites (L03.8), Constipation(K59.0), Ischiorectal abscess(K61.3), Anal fistula(K60.3), Other and unspecified cirrhosis of liver(K74.6), Malignant neoplasm of endocrine pancreas(C25.4), Polyneuropathy, unspecified(G62.9), Acquired absence of other organs(Z90.8) leaving him saturated in the morning. I expressed that this change was not made, and that it would not be made as it was not his wishes. She was thankful for this. Hem/onc notes regarding CLL also requested and consider referring for local follow-up. Regarding leg edema, she continues on Lasix 20 mg po bid. Tubi grip recommended, elevated feet when possible. Regarding concerns regarding foot care, resident/POA encouraged to go out to chiropody if that is there preference. Regarding poor intakes, accurate intakes have been requested. LATE ENTRY Note Text : Assessed on medical rounds. Resident has reported some urinary frequency including nocturia. She is slightly vague as a historian but it seems that this has been ongoing for months. She indicates that frequency improved when she was most recently treated for UTI but since symptoms have returned. No other lower UT symptoms noted. Continue with pain management. For panic, Lorazepam 0.5 mg po bid prn has been ordered. Monitor sleep pattern. Regarding elevated creatinine, ensure catheter is functioning well. LATE ENTRY Note Text : Assessed on medical rounds. Resident has had change in health condition over the past few days. On September 21st in the early morning she was noted to have low oxygen, with sats improving to 93% with supplemental oxygen via nasal prongs. Later the same day at 1800, sats were normal on room air, and on September 22nd sats were normal on room air. She was noted to be alert with good intakes. Yesterday September 23rd she was noted to be drowsy during the day, falling forward from her wheelchair to her knees. This was witnessed, no apparent injuries. Yesterday evening in bed it was documented that she was lethargic, with O2 sat noted to be 80% on room air. Other VS stable. O2 sat improved to 94% with 3 liters of oxygen via nasal prongs. Increased leg edema has been noted over recent days. No documented history of MI, CAD or CHF. Risk factors in her medical history include Type 2 diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and peripheral vascular disease. She also has a history of anemia. Due to BPSD with agitation, Risperidone recently started. current dose 0.375 mg po bid. BPSD significantly improved. Other relevant mediations include ES Citalopram 10 mg po daily, Bisoprolol 5 mg daily, ASA 81 mg daily, Enalapril 5 mg po daily, Amlodipine10 mg po, Statin and ferrous fumarate 300 mg po daily. This morning at the time of assessment she was seated in her wheelchair, awake, calm, pleasdant and interactive. She denied pain or respiratory symptoms. Color somewhat pale. Mucus membranes moist. Resps easy and regular at rest. Normal breath sounds audible bilaterally, few fine inspiratory rales at the bases. Pulse regular, quiet heart sounds, no significant murmur heard, rate control, abdomen soft and benign. Pitting edema present below theknees bilaterally. Tubi grips in place. Likely CHF. Monitor VS bid. Chest x-ray requested stat to be completed by STL or by RVH long term care program if needed. Supplement oxygen to maintain sats at 90%. Lasix 40 mg po bid will be added for three days, and then reduced to once daily. Bloodwork has been ordered, including tests with respect to identifying falls risk and PNP. Due to recently identified worsening anemia (Hb 76), CBC will be follow weekly as well as LUC given addition of Lasix. UrineR&M to look for blood loss. Unfortunately, fecal occult blood testing is no longer available. Continue with iron supplementation. Pantoprazole will be increased to bid. Follow. LATE ENTRY Note Text : Assessed on medical rounds. Resident has had frequent assessment and medication adjustment recently related to CHF. This morning, nursing expressed concern that BP could not be obtained. Resident appeared tired but responsive. HR within normal limits, rhythm irregular. O2 sat was noted to be low at 78% but improved on 2 liters of oxygen to 93%. At the time of my assessment, daughter was present at the bedside. Resident was in bed with head of bed elevated, awake but reported feeling tired. She reports that she previously felt SOB, but improved with O2 via nasal prongs. She denies any pain. Reduced appetite. Recent vitals reviewed, HR generally between 48 and 97, systolic BP between 89 and 134. Resident's color okay, no significant pallor, icterus or cyanosis. Mucus membranes moist. Pulse irregular, radial pulse palpable. Resps easy and regular, normal breath sounds bilaterally with no adventitial sounds except for a few inspiratory rales on the left. Leg edema shows improvement compared tolast assessment. CHF. Edema improved on Lasix 80 mg po bid, however resident may be volume deplete at this time, contributing to some degree of hypotension. However, based on palpable radial pulse, systolic BP likely to be at least 80. Ramipril has been reduced to 2.5 mg po daily and will be placed on hold at this time. Due to lower HR, Bisoprolol will be reduced to 2.5 mg po daily. Cardiology consult was booked for this afternoon, but due to health condition, she will not be going out to this appointment. Daughter will be in contact with cardiology office for possible virtual appointment or rescheduling. Treatment plan reviewed with POA/daughter at bedside, and she was agreeable with this plan. Also of note, dermatitis on the buttocks noted, images reviewed, order provided for Canesten/Hydrocortisone plus Calmoseptine bid and prn. Continue to follow closely. LATE ENTRY Note Text : Assessed on medical rounds. Resident notes ongoing lower leg edema. She continues to be non-compliant with tubigrip stockings. She reports some SOB on exertion today. Echocardiogram complete due to concerns for CHF. Results include AFIB, moderate LV dysfunction with ejection fraction 42%. Right systolic function somewhat diminished with right atrial dilation and moderate tricuspid regurgitation. Mild pulmonary hypertension also noted. VS have been stable, systolic BP between 100 and 120. HR within normal limits with documented heart rate of 60 to 95. O2 sats have been normal. At the time of rounds, resident was seated in chair in her room with her feet elevated. She appeared calm, comfortable and in no distress. Color okay, resps easy at rest. Pulse slightly irregular, rate normal. Normal breath sounds audible bilaterally with fine inspiratory rales in the left anterior field. Good breath sounds to bilateral bases. Bloodwork reviewed, CBC and LUC okay. AFIB, CHF. She continues on Apixaban for known AFIB. Diltiazem will be changed to Bisoprolol, follow regarding BP and rate control. She continues on reduced Ramipril 2.5 mg po once daily. Lasix will be increase to 80 mg po bid, continue with weekly weights. Tubi grip discontinued as resident is consistently refuses, despite health teaching. LUC will be completed weekly. Chest x-ray to assess previous pneumonia to rule out CHF. Continue to monitor VS bid. Cardiology referral as requested by POA. Dictated by Dr. Lee Andersen dictatedbut not read [e-SIGNED]

Data : Writer was informed by the Unit Supervisor and Skin + Wound Lead that the resident has new redness to his right thigh area; similar to the current pre-existing redness located on his left thigh; assessed by Skin + Wound Lead and Unit Supervisor earlier today. Action : As per the Unit Supervisor, the resident is frequently being repositioned in his wheelchair and also while in bed for offloading purposes. Previous information was thought to be that the resident's wheelchair could be a cause of the pressure, however, speaking with the Physiotherapist, the wheelchair is not the culprit; it's a repositioning piece and how the resident often shifts his position due to poor trunk control. Following the assessment, the recommendation was to reposition the resident hourly via mechanical lift. Response : The Writer called the resident's sister, Paola (POA for Personal Care) to update on the skin condition along with recommended intervention. During conversation, Paola expressed she felt that hourly reposition via mechanical lift will cause the resident too much stress which can further lead to seizures due to stress levels. She agreed for hourly reposition, however suggested to use the lift at a minimum and would rather have a 2 person manual reposition while in his wheelchair. The Writer explained that not all staff feel comfortable with this due to strength abilities but we'd do our best to accommodate this request; Paola very appreciative of the call and update provided. No voiced concerns.
